issue.title: v3.35.0 - ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'certifi'
issue.body:
# v3.35.0 - ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'certifi' 

## How to reproduce

### OS Info

M1 Mac : 14.0

### Steps

- Install the `oci-cli`

> Tried uninstall and installing 3 times

```bash
# To uninstall : brew uninstall oci-cli
# To reinstall : brew reinstall oci-cli
brew install oci-cli
```
- Run oci command

```bash
oci -h
```
 Output

```bash
..
..
 File "/opt/homebrew/Cellar/oci-cli/3.35.0/libexec/lib/python3.12/site-packages/oci/_vendor/requests/certs.py", line 20, in <module>
    from certifi import where
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'certifi'
```

I see that the package `v3.35.0` was released 20 hours back.

So as a workaround had to manually install [v3.34.0](https://github.com/oracle/oci-cli/releases/tag/v3.34.0) by following [docs.oracle.com » Manual and Offline Installations](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/climanualinst.htm#climanualinst_intro) which is working for the time being.

comment.body:
Yes, I also went the process of installing corresponding packages for `certifi` and then `six` errors. It might be become tedious and unpredictable by trying to make it work by installing packages manually. 
So I decided to downgrade the version of `oci-cli` to `v3.34.0`. It seems to be working fine for all of my requirements so far.

issue.title: Using oci cli not adminstrator mode
issue.body: can i use oci CLI as normal user not as admin user  ?

payload.description: Command Line Interface for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure

release.body:
## Added
* Support for new optional parameters in the list alarms status in the OCI Monitoring Service
  * ``oci monitoring alarm-status list-alarms-status --entity-id, --resource-id, --service-name, --status``
* Add support for creating/updating new connection types in the Goldengate service
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-amazon-kinesis-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-amazon-kinesis-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-amazon-redshift-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-amazon-redshift-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-elasticsearch-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-elasticsearch-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-generic-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-generic-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-google-big-query-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-google-big-query-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-google-cloud-storage-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-google-cloud-storage-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection create-redis-connection``
  * ``oci goldengate connection update-redis-connection``
* Support for managing replicas in the NoSQL service
  * ``oci nosql table create-replica``
  * ``oci nosql table update-replica``
* Application Dependency Management
  * Adds new commands for managing ADM Remediation resources
    * ``oci adm remediation-recipe``
    * ``oci adm remediation-run``
    * ``oci adm remediation-run-collection list-remediation-runs``
    * ``oci adm remediation-run-stage get-stage``
    * ``oci adm remediation-run-stage-collection list-stages``
    * ``oci adm application-dependency-recommendation-collection list-application-dependency-recommendations``
  * Fix bug where when creating a Vulnerability Audit, we now wait for the lifecycle state of the audit instead of its Work Request.
* Database Service
  * Support for new optional parameter in autonomous container database
    * ``oci db autonomous-container-database create --is-dst-file-update-enabled``
    * ``oci db autonomous-container-database update --is-dst-file-update-enabled``
  * Newly added api for creating maintenance run for ACD resources
    * ``oci db maintenance-run create``
* Database Tools
  * Support for the new Generic JDBC connection type
    * ``oci dbtools connection create-generic-jdbc``
    * ``oci dbtools connection update-generic-jdbc``
  * Support for the new Postgresql connection type
    * ``oci dbtools connection create-postgresql``
    * ``oci dbtools connection update-postgresql``
  * Support for connections without runtime support on existing connection types
    * ``oci dbtools connection create-oracle-database --runtime-support unsupported``
    * ``oci dbtools connection create-mysql-database --runtime-support unsupported``
  * Support for connection list filtering using the runtime-support property
    * ``oci dbtools connection list --runtime-support``
  * Support for proxy authentication on Oracle connections
    * ``oci dbtools connection create-oracle-database --proxy-client``
    * ``oci dbtools connection update-oracle-database --proxy-client``
  *  Support for resource locking
    * ``oci dbtools private-endpoint add-lock``
    * ``oci dbtools private-endpoint remove-lock``

## Changed
* [BREAKING] New required parameters in the Database Tools Service
  * ``oci dbtools connection create-mysql-database --connection-string --user-name``
  * ``oci dbtools connection create-oracle-database --connection-string --user-name``

## File Checksums (SHA256)
oci-cli-3.35.0.zip 7cd945df12c565f9a3df7d7e0612fe7f0c0fab71cf311bffba5b4c9cbe9122bb
release.short_description_html:
Added

  • Support for new optional parameters in the list alarms status in the OCI Monitoring Service
    • oci monitoring alarm-status list-alarms-status --entity-id, --resource-id, --service-name, --status

issue.title: How to avoid having to remember compartment ID??
issue.body:
Issue: when run a command like: `oci compute instance list`, I get this error:
```
Error: Missing option(s) --compartment-id.
```

I found a really old [issue from 2018](https://github.com/oracle/oci-cli/issues/47) that indicates that it should be possible. According to the docs for [Configuring the CLI/Specifying Default Values](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Default_Values), I should be able to add my compartment ID to the OCI configuration file to avoid being asked for it every time. But this doesn't work for me. My anonymized `~/.oci/config`:
```
[DEFAULT]
user = ocid1.user.oc1..blahblahblah
fingerprint = bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah
key_file = /home/blah/.oci/oci_api_key.pem
tenancy = ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
compartment-id = ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
region = eu-amsterdam-1
```

There doesn't seem to be a [CLI Environment Variable](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/clienvironmentvariables.htm) for compartment ID. I also tried adding this to the `~/.oci/config` (but didn't expect it to work anyway):
```
[OCI_CLI_SETTINGS]
default_profile=DEFAULT
```

I even went as far as reading all of the online docs and found an example of how to get the `oci` to automatically add the compartment-id value to an [aliased command](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Command_Aliases) where 'ls' alias is used for 'list'...
```
compute.instance.list.compartment-id=ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
```
...but that didn't work either!

Debug output from `oci os ns get --debug` shows that it's picking up the `compartment-id` from the config file:

```
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_metrics: 2023-05-07 10:09:16.007636: Metrics is not enabled
Linux-6.2.6-1-default-x86_64-with-glibc2.37
System name: Linux
System release : 6.2.6-1-default
System version: #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Mon Mar 13 10:57:27 UTC 2023 (fa1a4c6)

DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:Config File: dict_keys(['log_requests', 'additional_user_agent', 'pass_phrase', 'user', 'fingerprint', 'key_file', 'tenancy', 'compartment-id', 'region'])
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:region: Environment Variable or Parameter
```

comment.body:
Welcome @spareslant 
I think a single unified config file would have required all tools (and tools build on top of them) to be aware of each others config params and would have also brought in conflict if any params ended up being common, unintentionally.

So I am closing this issue for now, and I can still answer any future questions here.

comment.body: Hi @karthik-k-kamath , Thanks for the explanation. I think confusion is, why there is an additional config file for cli. Both SDK and cli could have used a single unified config file giving a simple seem less config experience to the users. I am sure CLI might be using SDK behind the scenes. Feel free to close this issue.

```
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:Config File: dict_keys(['log_requests', 'additional_user_agent', 'pass_phrase', 'user', 'fingerprint', 'key_file', 'tenancy', 'compartment-id', 'region'])
```

comment.body:
Hi @spareslant , thanks for the questions, I understand your confusion.
Let  me help clarify.
The `~/.oci/config` file the common configuration file for all OCI tools: CLI, SDKs etc
This doc explains it better: [SDK and CLI Configuration File](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/sdkconfig.htm)

The `~/.oci/oci_cli_rc` is an additional config file meant only for OCI CLI to use, it way CLI provides it's users lot more configuration features that `~/.oci/config` does not like: command aliases, names queries etc which are relevant only in CLI scope.
My suggestion is to only edit `~/.oci/oci_cli_rc` file and keep `~/.oci/config` untouched when using OCI CLI.
Is there any param/usage that you find **not** possible in `~/.oci/oci_cli_rc` file, for which you had to edit `~/.oci/config` ?

issue.title: How to avoid having to remember compartment ID??
issue.body:
Issue: when run a command like: `oci compute instance list`, I get this error:
```
Error: Missing option(s) --compartment-id.
```

I found a really old [issue from 2018](https://github.com/oracle/oci-cli/issues/47) that indicates that it should be possible. According to the docs for [Configuring the CLI/Specifying Default Values](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Default_Values), I should be able to add my compartment ID to the OCI configuration file to avoid being asked for it every time. But this doesn't work for me. My anonymized `~/.oci/config`:
```
[DEFAULT]
user = ocid1.user.oc1..blahblahblah
fingerprint = bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah
key_file = /home/blah/.oci/oci_api_key.pem
tenancy = ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
```

```
[OCI_CLI_SETTINGS]
default_profile=DEFAULT
```

I even went as far as reading all of the online docs and found an example of how to get the `oci` to automatically add the compartment-id value to an [aliased command](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Command_Aliases) where 'ls' alias is used for 'list'...

comment.body:
> Hi @raffraffraff , @spareslant , I think you may have misunderstood `~/.oci/config` as the CLI config file. The CLI config file is **`~/.oci/oci_cli_rc`** and not `~/.oci/config`
> 
> This is clearly mention here: [CLI Configuration File](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#CLIconfigfile)
> 
> > CLI Configuration File
> > The default location and file name for the CLI-specific configuration file is ~/.oci/oci_cli_rc ...
> 
> This should explain why your command started working only after you added the default value in ~/.oci/oci_cli_rc Hope this helps, and let me know if I can help answer any other query.

Hi @karthik-k-kamath , if **`~/.oci/oci_cli_rc`**  is called as a CLI config file, what to call **`~/.oci/config`** file then? 

Leaving the naming convention aside,  the point is  It has been understood, how these works. Its the design and ergonomics of using these files that people are complaining/questioning about.  One set of params for a profile/section can be defined only in one file and and other set of params are for another file for same profile/section. This is not flexible. Natural way of thinking is to be able to use all params under a profile.  Is there a document that specify what params are effective  in `~/.oci/config` file and not in `~/.oci/oci_cli_rc`  and also vice-versa ?

```
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_metrics: 2023-05-07 10:09:16.007636: Metrics is not enabled
Linux-6.2.6-1-default-x86_64-with-glibc2.37
System name: Linux
System release : 6.2.6-1-default
System version: #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Mon Mar 13 10:57:27 UTC 2023 (fa1a4c6)

DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:Config File: dict_keys(['log_requests', 'additional_user_agent', 'pass_phrase', 'user', 'fingerprint', 'key_file', 'tenancy', 'compartment-id', 'region'])
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:region: Environment Variable or Parameter
```

comment.body:
Hi @raffraffraff , @spareslant , I think you may have misunderstood `~/.oci/config` as the CLI config file.
The CLI config file is **`~/.oci/oci_cli_rc`** and not  `~/.oci/config`

This is clearly mention here: [CLI Configuration File](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#CLIconfigfile)
>CLI Configuration File
>The default location and file name for the CLI-specific configuration file is ~/.oci/oci_cli_rc ...

This should explain why your command started working only after you added the default value in ~/.oci/oci_cli_rc
Hope this helps, and let me know if I can help answer any other query.

issue.title: How to avoid having to remember compartment ID??
issue.body:
Issue: when run a command like: `oci compute instance list`, I get this error:
```
Error: Missing option(s) --compartment-id.
```

I found a really old [issue from 2018](https://github.com/oracle/oci-cli/issues/47) that indicates that it should be possible. According to the docs for [Configuring the CLI/Specifying Default Values](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Default_Values), I should be able to add my compartment ID to the OCI configuration file to avoid being asked for it every time. But this doesn't work for me. My anonymized `~/.oci/config`:
```
[DEFAULT]
user = ocid1.user.oc1..blahblahblah
fingerprint = bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah:bl:ah
key_file = /home/blah/.oci/oci_api_key.pem
tenancy = ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
compartment-id = ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
region = eu-amsterdam-1
```

There doesn't seem to be a [CLI Environment Variable](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/clienvironmentvariables.htm) for compartment ID. I also tried adding this to the `~/.oci/config` (but didn't expect it to work anyway):
```
[OCI_CLI_SETTINGS]
default_profile=DEFAULT
```

I even went as far as reading all of the online docs and found an example of how to get the `oci` to automatically add the compartment-id value to an [aliased command](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Command_Aliases) where 'ls' alias is used for 'list'...
```
compute.instance.list.compartment-id=ocid1.tenancy.oc1..blahblahblah
```
...but that didn't work either!

Debug output from `oci os ns get --debug` shows that it's picking up the `compartment-id` from the config file:

```
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_metrics: 2023-05-07 10:09:16.007636: Metrics is not enabled
Linux-6.2.6-1-default-x86_64-with-glibc2.37
System name: Linux
System release : 6.2.6-1-default
System version: #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Mon Mar 13 10:57:27 UTC 2023 (fa1a4c6)

DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:Config File: dict_keys(['log_requests', 'additional_user_agent', 'pass_phrase', 'user', 'fingerprint', 'key_file', 'tenancy', 'compartment-id', 'region'])
DEBUG:oci_cli.cli_util:region: Environment Variable or Parameter
```

comment.body:
> Oh WOW, this is stupid... So `oci` completely ignores the compartment-id in your `~/.oci/config` when you run a command that requires `--compartment-id`. But if you add it to `~/.oci/oci_cli_rc` then this works. So I can literally `cp ~/.oci/config ~/.oci/oci_cli_rc` to fix this.
> 
> This is daft. It should use the compartment ID from the `~/.oci/config`. But feel free to close this if you disagree. People will at least be able to find this with a google/github search.
> 
> The doc for [Specifying Default Values](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliconfigure.htm#Specifying_Default_Values) should explain this a lot better - like specifically calling out that you can't just use `~/.oci/config` to do this, because it is ignoring the value in that file.

+1 for this issue.

comment.body:
Hi, can you try one of these upgrade steps mentioned here, to rule out nay local issues: 
[Upgrading the CLI](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/cliupgrading.htm)

If you still face error, then I recommend installing CLI in a separate virtual environment using: 
[Manual Installation](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/SDKDocs/climanualinst.htm#climanualinst_intro)

payload.description: Command Line Interface for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure

release.body:
## Added
* Support for the new Redis service
  * ``oci redis``
* Support for export Container and Kubernetes application listings in the Marketplace Service
  * ``oci marketplace-publisher``
* Support for achieving higher limits in the Network Firewall Service
  * ``oci network-firewall address-list``
  * ``oci network-firewall application``
  * ``oci network-firewall application-group``
  * ``oci network-firewall decryption-profile``
  * ``oci network-firewall decryption-rule``
  * ``oci network-firewall mapped-secret``
  * ``oci network-firewall network-firewall-policy``
  * ``oci network-firewall security-rule``
  * ``oci network-firewall service``
  * ``oci network-firewall service-list``
  * ``oci network-firewall url-list``
* Support for exporting access request reports in the Managed Access Service
  * ``oci oma lockbox export-access-requests``
* Support for Mount File System in Data Science Jobs and Notebooks in the Data Science Service
  * ``oci data-science job create --job-storage-mount-configuration-details-list``
  * ``oci data-science job update --job-storage-mount-configuration-details-list``
  * ``oci data-science notebook-session create --notebook-session-storage-mount-configuration-details-list``
  * ``oci data-science notebook-session update --notebook-session-storage-mount-configuration-details-list``
* Logging Management
  * Support for unified agent operational metrics for the service configuration option
    * ``oci logging agent-configuration``
  * Added new destination field in the option ``--service-configuration``

## Changed
* [BREAKING] Optional parameter ``--auto-approval-state`` was removed in the Managed Access Service
  * ``oci oma lockbox update``
* [BREAKING] Optional parameter ``--service-stage`` was removed in the Logging Management Service
  * ``oci logging service list``
* [BREAKING] Optional parameters ``--application-lists, --decryption-profiles, --decryption-rules, --ip-address-lists, --mapped-secrets, --security-rules, --url-lists`` were removed in the Network Firewall Service
  * ``oci network-firewall network-firewall-policy create``
  * ``oci network-firewall network-firewall-policy update``

## File Checksums (SHA256)
oci-cli-3.34.0.zip e0de51a4a003e4b361d335bad88d2bdd43278309f265b9f0a1ddde66d7a7cfc0

Added

  • Support for the new Redis service
    • oci redis
  • Support for export Container and Kubernetes application listings in the Marketplace Service
    • oci marketplace-publisher
  • Support for achieving …
